titlestmt.titleproper: Ima Joy Chodorow Gandler Texas Jewish collection, Inclusive: 1827-2009, undated, Bulk: 1972-2004

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Ima Joy Chodorow Gandler Texas Jewish collection

physdesc.extent: 45 document boxes, 2 oversize boxes, 1 oversize folder

did.abstract: The Ima Joy Chodorow Gandler Texas Jewish collection houses Ima Joy Gandler’s family and personal papers as well as genealogical information of Waco Jewish families. Gandler’s participation and interests in numerous organizations is also documented. Items include clippings, correspondence, newsletters, bulletins, photographs, legal documents, organizational records, and other print materials and audiovisual media.
did.langmaterial: English, Hebrew, Italian, Russian, and Spanish

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Ima Joy Chodorow Gandler was born 1929 October 25 in Waco, Texas, to Nathan and Miriam Borschow Chodorow. She was a 1946 Waco High School graduate and attended the University of Texas. Ima Joy Chodorow married Jacob E. "Jake" Gandler on 1950 June 25 and they had three children; Sharlane Michaele, Laura, and Howard.

As an active member of Waco Temple Rodef Sholom, Ima Joy Gandler began collecting materials on Texas Jewish Culture in the 1970s as the Temple neared its 100th Anniversary. She began with a local archive to document each confirmation class and moved on to document the history of the Waco Jewish Community as well as Jewish Communities across Texas.

In 1980 Ima Joy became a founding member of the Texas Jewish Historical Society and promoted the interest of Texas Jewish History locally, throughout Texas, and the United States. She was also an active member in organizations such as the National Council of Jewish Women, National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods, Jewish Federation of Waco and Central Texas, and the Greater Waco Interfaith Conference. Her participation often included the role of archivist, board member, or other governing title.

In addition to her religious interests, Gandler used her research skills to further her genealogical searches and help others do the same. In doing so she was able to collect several family histories from the Waco Jewish Community. Ima Joy was also a patron of the arts and enjoyed travel. She regularly supported the Waco Hippodrome Theatre as a season ticket holder and visited larger cities such as Dallas and New York to attend shows as well.
Ima Joy Gandler died on 2010 January 25. She is buried at Rodef Sholom Cemetery in Waco, Texas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Ima Joy Gandler’s personal interests and community involvement contributed to a broad collection of Waco and Texas Jewish history which she distributed as photocopies and original materials to repositories such as the American Jewish Archives in Cincinnati, Ohio; the Dolph Briscoe Center for American History at the University of Texas in Austin, and The Texas Collection at Baylor University in Waco, Texas. The Ima Joy Chodorow Gandler Texas Jewish Collection houses Gandler’s personal and family papers in addition to highlighting her genealogical interests and participation with numerous organizations.

The Family series consists of materials produced by and about Gandler’s family. The Borschows, Chodorows, and Gandlers provide a bulk of the information, but other branches are represented as well. The Personal series is an extension of family papers but focus specifically on Ima Joy’s activities. Her interests in the arts, travel, research, and personal relationships are documented in addition to her philanthropic and organizational participation. An original manuscript and printed copy of the book Pioneer Jews of Waco by Rabbi Mordecai Podet are also included.

The Genealogy series consists of original and photocopied materials documenting activities, events, and accomplishments of individuals and families within the Waco Jewish Community. Documentation shows that original materials were made available to Ima Joy Gandler and returned to the families after photocopying with knowledge that the information would be distributed through the Texas Collection at Baylor University and [Waco] Temple Rodef Sholom. Multiple generations of families with deep ties to the Waco Jewish Community are documented as well as several others who once lived in the area but have moved away. Notable names include Englander, Goldstein, Sanger, Levy, Naman, Lipsitz, and Harelik. Also included are notecards created by Gandler which outline family lineages.

The Organizations series documents Gandler’s involvement and interests in the broader Jewish Community. As a member of local, regional, and national organizations she collected materials of such groups as the Greater Waco Interfaith Conference, National Council for Jewish Women, and the Texas Jewish Historical Society (TJHS). She also collected material on Jewish congregations throughout Texas, identifying lost or dwindling Jewish communities in addition to those still thriving. Organizations she supported financially can also be found. Some include the Greene Family Camp, Texas A&M Hillel, and the United States Holocaust Memorial. Information on each organization varies based upon Ima Joy’s involvement from casual interest to active member or officer. This is most evident in congregational files as some have only one or two items while others are more robust with multiple files.

In the General series, groups of records that did not accurately fit into another series are collected. Material related to the Archie Hoppenstein papers and items from Lena Lynn and the Jolly Huaco Garden Club are present. Land title abstracts and deeds are also included as there is no clear connection to whom they belonged.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection had no previous order. Items are now arranged into five series: I. Family, II. Personal, III. Genealogy, IV. Organizations, and V. General.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ima Joy Chodorow Gandler Texas Jewish collection, Accession #855, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Sylvia Hernandez. Released on 2020-02-11.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Family series is dated 1900-2006 and contains records and general information regarding Ima Joy’s Borschow, Chodorow, and Gandler relatives. Materials include legal documents, photographs, newspaper clippings, correspondence, certificates and ledgers. The series is arranged alphabetically and is in good condition.

Gandler, Jacob and Ima Joy: Rental Property Ledgers

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Personal series, dated 1876-2009, documents the works, interests, and life of Ima Joy Gandler. Clippings, photographs, annual reports, newsletters, invitations, correspondence, greeting cards, research notes, pamphlets, and other printed material are included. The series is arranged alphabetically by topic and is in good condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Genealogy series, dated 1827 -2009, includes items such as legal documents, immigration papers, birth announcements, obituaries, and newspaper clippings. Also included are certificates and invitations for various events including confirmations, bar/bat mitzvahs, weddings, and birthdays. Photographs and reproduction photographs have been included as well. The series is arranged alphabetically by family surname. The series is in good condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Organizations series is dated 1873-2009. Newsletters, correspondence, research materials, bulletins, and clippings make up the bulk of the items. Other materials include guestbooks, clippings, directories, minutes, announcements, and other printed material. The series is arranged alphabetically by organization and is in good condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The General series is dated 1924-1996. Title abstracts, property records, correspondence, clippings, research notes, committee engagement notes, organizational directories, and handbooks are present. The series is in alphabetical order and in good condition.
